{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Massimo Moratti |image = Moratti particolare.JPG |imagesize = 250px |caption = Moratti in 2009 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|5|16|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Bosco Chiesanuova]], [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]] |occupation = entrepreneur | known_for = {{ubl|Co-owner of [[Saras S.p.A.|Saras]]|Former Owner of [[Inter Milan]]}} | boards = {{ubl|Saras (Director & CEO)|{{nowrap|Internazionale (Chairman, until 2013)}}}} |nationality = Italian | net worth = [[US$]]1.6 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (November 2018)<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/ Forbes 2018 list]</ref><ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/massimo-moratti/]</ref> |spouse = Milly Moratti |children = 5 }} '''Massimo Moratti''' (born 16 May 1945) is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[petroleum]] [[tycoon]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] (CEO) of the [[Saras S.p.A.|Saras Group]], founded in 1962 by his father, industrialist [[Angelo Moratti]]; the main production site of the Saras Group is the Sarroch refinery located on the island of [[Sardinia]], one of Europe's only six supersites, with a capacity of 300,000 barrels per day, representing 15% of refining capacity in Italy. In recent years, initially to enable independence of the Sarroch refinery from terms of energy, the Saras Group has entered in the production of electricity and is expanding its production of alternative energy sources, particularly in the field of wind energy, through its subsidiaries Sarlux and Sardeolica, the latter of which is controlled indirectly through the company Eolici Ulassai.
From 1995 until 2013, Moratti was the chairman of [[Inter Milan|F.C. Internazionale Milano]]. He is said to have spent around €1.5 billion of his personal fortune in the transfer market,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.thescore.com/counterattack/2013/09/26/bandini-massimo-morattis-inter-legacy-nears-its-end-as-he-prepares-to-sell/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140702053647/http://blogs.thescore.com/counterattack/2013/09/26/bandini-massimo-morattis-inter-legacy-nears-its-end-as-he-prepares-to-sell/ |archivedate=2 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and was famous for signing numerous football superstars.
He was Inter's honorary chairman, and also a [[United Nations]] [[Goodwill Ambassador]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In 2013, he was inducted into the [[Italian Football Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/27-10-2015/hall-of-fame-vialli-mancini-facchetti-ronaldo-herrera-agnelli-tardelli-ferlaino-130676725232.shtml|title=Hall of fame, 10 new entry: con Vialli e Mancini anche Facchetti e Ronaldo|trans-title=Hall of fame, 10 new entries: with Vialli and Mancini also Facchetti and Ronaldo|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref>
==Life and career== Massimo Moratti is the fourth son of industrialist [[Angelo Moratti]], who was the chairman of [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Football Club Internazionale Milano]] during the team's "Golden Age" from 1955 to 1968. Born in the family villa in the [[Bosco Chiesanuova]], close to [[Verona]], he graduated from [[Libera Università Internazionale degli Studi Sociali Guido Carli]] with a master's degree in [[Political Science]]. [[File:1966–67 Serie A - AC Mantova v Inter Milan - Gian Marco, Massimo and Angelo Moratti.jpg|thumb|left|Gian Marco, Massimo and [[Angelo Moratti]] in 1967]]
[[Letizia Moratti]], his brother's wife, was the Mayor of Milan from 2006 until 2011.
On his father's death, Massimo Moratti inherited his shares in the Saras Group, engaged in the refining of petroleum, where he is presently C.E.O. Moratti is also the owner of Sarlux, headquartered in [[Cagliari]], which focuses on the production of electricity from the waste oil.
Married to the environmental activist Emilia Moratti (née Bossi), the couple have five children. On 10 September 2009, Sauro Gori announced that Moratti had been appointed a [[United Nations]] [[Goodwill Ambassador]].
In May 2011, Moratti supported [[Giuliano Pisapia]]'s bid to become mayor of Milan against his sister-in-law [[Letizia Moratti |Letizia]]. His call for 'change' was perceived as an extension of his rivalry with [[A.C. Milan]], [[Silvio Berlusconi]], from football to the political sphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newnotizie.it/2011/05/26/massimo-moratti-pisapia-berlusconi-autogol|title=Massimo Moratti a sostegno di Pisapia: Berlusconi fa solo autogol|publisher=newnotizie.it|accessdate=2011-06-01 }}</ref>
==Chairman of Inter== Moratti took over as chairman of Inter from Ernesto Pellegrini in 1995, during a period where many considered Inter to be underachievers. During the 18 years of his leadership, Inter has clinched five [[Serie A|Scudetti/Serie A]] in a row from 2006 to 2010 (equalling the all-time record), four [[Coppa Italia]] titles (2005, 2006, 2010, 2011), four [[Supercoppa Italiana]] titles (2005, 2006, 2008, 2010), one [[UEFA Champions League]] (2010), one [[FIFA Club World Cup]] (2010) and one [[UEFA Cup]] (1998). Inter won the Scudetto, the Coppa Italia and the Champions League in the 2009-2010 season, becoming the first Italian team that managed to achieve the [[Treble (association football)|Treble]].
Moratti is said to have spent around €1.5 billion of his personal fortune in the transfer market in his time as chairman. His most famous signing was that of [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] from [[FC Barcelona]] in the summer of 1997, at a time when he was widely considered the best player in the world. Later, in July 1999, Moratti sanctioned a then world-record €48 million purchase of striker [[Christian Vieri]] and has purchased numerous other superstars, including [[Roberto Carlos (footballer)|Roberto Carlos]], [[Hernán Crespo]], [[Adriano Leite Ribeiro|Adriano]], [[Iván Zamorano]], [[Maicon Douglas Sisenando|Maicon]], [[Roberto Baggio]], [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]], [[Luís Figo]], [[Patrick Vieira]], [[Samuel Eto'o]], [[David Suazo]] and [[Wesley Sneijder]].
However, criticism also been levelled against Moratti, as he fired coaches frequently. Except keeping [[Giuseppe Baresi]] and [[Daniele Bernazzani]] as backroom staff in the first team or in the youth system, as well as [[Marco Branca]] as one of the directors, the team had changed from [[Rafael Benítez]], [[Leonardo Araújo|Leonardo]], [[Gian Piero Gasperini|Gasperini]] and most recently [[Claudio Ranieri|Ranieri]] in just 2 seasons. [[Roberto Mancini]] and [[José Mourinho]] were the only two trophy winning and longest serving coach in recent years. Before Mancini, Massimo employed more than 10 short-lived coaches, including [[Roy Hodgson]], [[Marcello Lippi]], [[Marco Tardelli]], [[Héctor Cúper]] and [[Alberto Zaccheroni]].
The day after Ranieri was dismissed, chief scout of the first team Giovanni Battista Lanfranchi was fired and replaced by the former technical commission of Udinese, Valentino Angeloni.<ref>http://www.inter.it/aas/news/reader?N=39516&L=en</ref> Lanfranchi had served for Inter for 13 years<ref>http://www.inter.it/aas/news/reader?N=57259&L=it</ref> in different positions.
On 15 November 2013, International Sports Capital took control of 70% of the club. Indonesian businessman [[Erick Thohir]], a part-owner of that company, was elected chairman of Inter, but Moratti remained with the club as the honorary chairman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inter.it/en/news/44183 |title=F.C. Internazionale statement |publisher=F.C. Internazioanle Milano |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>
On 28 June 2016 Massimo Moratti's Internazionale Holding S.r.l. sold all its stake in [[Inter Milan|F.C. Internazionale Milano S.p.A.]] to [[Erick Thohir]]'s Nusantara Sports Ventures HK Limited for €60 million (and re-sold to [[Zhang Jindong]]'s [[Suning Holdings Group]]). As of 2018, Massimo Moratti's wife, Milly Moratti, remained in the advisory board of Inter. However, Massimo Moratti himself, was no longer the honorary chairman of the club.<ref name=organigramma>{{cite web |url=http://www.inter.it/it/organigramma |title=organigramma|trans-title=Organization Chart |publisher=F.C. Internazionale Milano |accessdate=13 November 2018|date=October 2018}}</ref> Other member of Moratti family, Angelomario Moratti, Carlotta Moratti, Giovanni Moratti, remained as the member of the board of a subsidiary of the club, Inter Futura.<ref name=organigramma/>
==See also== *[[Letizia Moratti]] (Massimo Moratti's Sister-in-law; Gian Marco's wife. Former mayor of [[Milan]])

[[OMV]] ([[Austria]])
[[Transgaz]] ([[Romania]]) | length_km = 1329 | discharge = 10 to 23 billion cubic metres per year | diameter_in = 48 | direction = east–west | start = [[Strandzha]], [[Bulgaria]] | finish = [[Baumgarten an der March]], [[Austria]] | expected = 2018 | est = | through = [[Lozenets, Yambol Province|Lozenets]], [[Oryahovo]], [[Port of Bechet]], [[Nădlac]], [[Dolj County|Dolj]], [[Mehedinţi County|Mehedinti]], [[Caraş-Severin County|Caras-Severin]], [[Timiş County|Timiş]], and [[Arad County|Arad]] | par = }} The '''Nabucco-West pipeline''' (also referred to as the '''Turkey–Austria gas pipeline''') was a proposed [[natural gas]] [[pipeline transport|pipeline]] from the [[Turkey|Turkish]]-[[Bulgaria]]n border to [[Austria]]. It was a modification of the original Nabucco Pipeline project, which was to run from [[Erzurum]] in [[Turkey]] to [[Baumgarten an der March]] in [[Austria]]. The aim of the Nabucco pipeline was to diversify the natural gas suppliers and delivery routes for Europe, thus reducing [[Russia in the European energy sector|European dependence on Russian energy]]. The original project was backed by several [[European Union]] member states and by the [[United States]], and was seen as a rival to the [[South Stream]] pipeline project. The main supplier was expected to be [[Iraq]], with potential supplies from [[Azerbaijan]], [[Turkmenistan]], and [[Egypt]]. {{cite news |url = http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=nabucco-venture-sees-iraq-as-top-supplier-2010-09-30 |title = Nabucco venture sees Iraq as top supplier |agency = [[Hürriyet Daily News and Economic Review]] |date = 30 September 2010 |accessdate = 11 October 2010}} The main supply for the Nabucco West was to be [[Shah Deniz]] gas through the proposed [[Trans-Anatolian gas pipeline]] (TANAP). The project was developed by a consortium of six companies. Preparations started in 2002 and the intergovernmental agreement between Turkey, [[Romania]], Bulgaria, [[Hungary]] and Austria was signed on 13 July 2009. After an announcement of the construction of TANAP, the consortium submitted the Nabucco-West project. {{cite news |url= http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Bswords%5D=8fd5893941d69d0be3f378576261ae3e&tx_ttnews%5Bany_of_the_words%5D=Nabucco&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=39403&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=7&cHash=14f7efa1e66ef7e25b71f9df7b13dfff II Decision a Setback for Planned European Gas Highway |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=29 June 2013 |work = Publics.bg}} ==Motivation== {{Main|Russia in the European energy sector}} The Nabucco project is backed by the [[European Union]] and the [[United States]]. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/UK_SMALLCAPSRPT/idUKL2212241120080222 | title = U.S. throws weight behind EU's Nabucco pipeline | agency = [[Reuters]] | first = Paul | last = Taylor | date = 22 February 2008 | accessdate = 23 February 2008}} {{cite news |url = https://www.upi.com/Analysis-Europes-pipeline-war/24561202258576/ |title = Analysis: Europe's pipeline war |first = Stefan |last = Nicola |publisher = [[United Press International]] |date = 5 February {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLD60806920090713?sp=true | title = Turkish PM says wants Nabucco to transport Iran gas | first1 = Thomas | last1 = Grove | first2 = Orhan | last2 = Coskun | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 13 July 2009 | accessdate = 13 July 2009}} {{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1910123,00.html | work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | title= Europe Tries to Break Its Russian Gas Habit | first= Leo | last = Cendrowicz | date=13 July 2009 | accessdate=13 July 2009}} In the Trans-European Networks - Energy (TEN - E) programme, the Nabucco pipeline is designated as a project of strategic importance. {{cite journal |url = http://ec.europa.eu/energy/infrastructure/tent_e/doc/axis/2009_axis_linking_activity_report_2007_2009.pdf |title = Project of European Interest № NG3. Activity Report September 2007 - February 2009 |publisher = [[European Commission]] |last = van Aartsen |first = Jozias |authorlink = Jozias van Aartsen |format = PDF |date = 4 February 2009 https://web.archive.org/web/20100108035844/http://ec.europa.eu/energy/infrastructure/tent_e/doc/axis/2009_axis_linking_activity_report_2007_2009.pdf |archivedate = 8 January 2010 |df = dmy-all }} {{cite journal | url= http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2006:262:0001:0023:EN:PDF | title= Decision No 1364/2006/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 September 2006 laying down guidelines for trans-European energy networks (TEN-E) | publisher= [[European Commission]] | format = PDF | date=22 September 2006 | accessdate=25 January 2010}} An objective of the project is to connect the European Union better to the natural gas sources in the [[Caspian Sea]] and the [[Middle East]] regions. {{cite journal |url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/sites/ener/files/documents/2009_nabucco_decision_romania_en.pdf |title = Exemption decision on the Romanian section of the Nabucco pipeline |publisher = [[European Commission]] |format = PDF |accessdate = 11 February 2018}} {{cite journal |url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/sites/ener/files/documents/2009_nabucco_decison_hungary_hu.pdf |title = Exemption decision on the Hungarian section of the Nabucco pipeline |publisher = [[European Commission]] |format = PDF |language = Hungarian |accessdate = 11 February 2018}} {{cite journal |url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/sites/ener/files/documents/2009_nabucco_decision_bulgaria_en.pdf |title = Exemption decision on the Bulgarian section of the Nabucco pipeline |publisher = [[European Commission]] |format = PDF |accessdate = 11 February 2018}} The project has been driven by the intention to diversify its current energy supplies, and to lessen [[Russia in the European energy sector|European dependence on Russian energy]]—the biggest supplier of gas to Europe. {{cite news | url = http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0,1518,635921,00.html | title = Independence Day For European Gas | publisher = [[Der Spiegel|Spiegel Online International]] | date = 13 July 2009 | accessdate = 17 January 2010}} {{cite news | work = [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] | url = http://www.france24.com/en/20090127-eu-backs-nabucco-pipeline-get-off-russian-gas-energy | title = EU backs Nabucco pipeline to get off Russian gas | publisher = [[France 24]] | date = 27 January 2009 | accessdate = 17 January 2010}} The [[Russia–Ukraine gas disputes]] have been one of the factors driving the search for alternative suppliers, sources, and routes. {{cite news | first = Ahto | last = Lobjakas | url = http://www.rferl.org/content/Strategic_Nabucco_Deal_To_Reduce_Dependence_On_Russian_Gas/1775655.html | title = 'Strategic' Nabucco Deal Inked To Help Curb Dependence On Russian Gas | publisher = [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|RFE/RL]] | date = 13 July 2009 | accessdate = 17 January 2010}} Moreover, as per the [[European Commission]], Europe's gas consumption is expected to increase from 502 billion cubic metres, in 2005, to 815 billion cubic metres in 2030, which would mean Russia alone would not be able to meet the demand. {{cite news | first = Judy | last = Dempsey | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/23/business/global/23fischer.html | title = Hoping for More Than Just Energy From a Pipeline | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = 22 December 2009 | accessdate = 23 December 2009}} [[Southeast Europe|South Eastern Europe]] is important as many of the regions are heavily dependent on [[Russia]]n gas imports. Nabucco aims to diversify the gas supply to increase competition and security. [[Simon Pirani]], senior research fellow, [[Oxford Institute for Energy Studies]] presented to delegates at the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] Energy Forum in 2013 a list of prices from the Russian newspaper [[Izvestia]]: "What they show is the prices at which Russian gas is being purchased in different European countries, and this tells quite a simple story. If you're in Eastern Europe, and you are quite heavily dependent on Russian gas, you pay more than $500/TCM; if you're in the UK, where we have a pretty much complete domination of gas-to-gas market, you pay $300, or $370+ in Germany, which is somewhere in between."{{cite web | title=Eastern Europe: Import Dependence, Higher Prices | url=http://www.naturalgaseurope.com/eastern-europe-gas-import-dependence- |publisher=Naturalgaseurope.com | date=2 April 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} ==History== Preparations for the Nabucco project started in February 2002 when first talks took place between Austrian [[OMV]] and Turkish [[BOTAŞ]]. In June 2002, five companies (OMV of Austria, [[MOL Group]] of Hungary, [[Bulgargaz]] of Bulgaria, [[Transgaz]] of Romania and BOTAŞ of Turkey) signed a protocol of intention to construct the Nabucco pipeline. The protocol followed by the cooperation agreement in October 2002. The name ''[[Nabucco]]'' comes from the same famous [[opera]] of [[Giuseppe Verdi]], that the five partners had listened to at the [[Vienna State Opera]] after this meeting. {{cite web |url = http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/press-public-news/q-a/q-a.html |title = Frequently asked questions: Nabucco Gas Pipeline Project |publisher = Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH |accessdate = 8 May 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100429233209/http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/press-public-news/q-a/q-a.html |archivedate = 29 April 2010 |df = dmy-all }} In December 2003, the [[European Commission]] awarded a grant in the amount of 50% of the estimated total eligible cost of the feasibility study including market analysis, and technical, economic and financial studies. On 28 June 2005, the joint venture agreement was signed by five Nabucco partners. The ministerial statement on the Nabucco pipeline was signed on 26 June 2006 in Vienna. {{cite conference |url = http://www.kormanyszovivo.hu/media/retreive_file/14828?lang=hu |title = Declaration of the Budapest Nabucco Summit |publisher = Budapest Nabucco Summit |date = 27 January 2009 |accessdate = 31 January 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090718190013/http://www.kormanyszovivo.hu/media/retreive_file/14828?lang=hu |archivedate = 18 July 2009 |df = dmy-all }} On 12 September 2007, [[Jozias van Aartsen]] was nominated by the [[European Commission]] as the Nabucco project coordinator. {{cite news | url = http://www.euractiv.com/en/energy/hopes-revived-stalled-nabucco-pipeline/article-166800 | title = Hopes revived for stalled Nabucco pipeline | publisher = EurActiv | date = 18 September 2007 | accessdate = 5 July 2009}} In February 2008, German [[RWE]] became a shareholder of the consortium. {{cite news | url = http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article142723.ece | title = RWE keen on Nabucco supplies | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | date = 19 https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/11/business/worldbusiness/11iht-pipe.4.13640390.html?_r=1 | first = Judy | last = Dempsey | title = EU natural gas pipeline project gets first order | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = 11 June 2008 | accessdate = 15 July 2010}} The [[President of Azerbaijan]] [[Ilham Aliyev]] confirmed on 29 January 2009, that Azerbaijan was planning to at least double its gas production in the coming five years to supply the pipeline. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKWLA618820090129 | title = DAVOS-Azeri chief urges political, financial will for Nabucco | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 29 January 2009 | accessdate = 31 January 2009}} On 12 April 2009, the Minister of Energy of Turkey [[Hilmi Güler]] confirmed that Turkey is ready to sign a deal, provided that Turkey gets 15% of the natural gas to be carried through the Nabucco pipeline. {{cite news |url = http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/71937/turkey-hopes-to-sign-nabucco-deal-by-june.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090813212413/http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/71937/turkey-hopes-to-sign-nabucco-deal-by-june.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 13 August 2009 |title = Turkey Hopes to Sign Nabucco Deal by June |publisher = [[Journal of Turkish Weekly]] |date = 16 April 2009 |accessdate = 16 April 2009 }} On 27 January 2009, the Nabucco Summit held in Budapest. {{cite news | url = http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,3980038,00.html | title = Proposed Nabucco Gas Pipeline Gets European Bank Backing | publisher = [[Deutsche Welle]] | date = 27 January 2009 | accessdate = 31 Nabucco Summits Begins | publisher = Turkish Press | date = 13 July 2009 | accessdate = 13 July 2009}} {{cite press release | url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2009/july/125968.htm | title = = [[Reuters]] | first = Balazs | last = Koranyi | date = 20 October 2009 | accessdate = 8 January 2010}} Bulgaria ratified the agreement on 3 February 2010. {{cite news | url = The main elements of the PSAs are the affirmation of an advantageous regulatory transit regime under EU law; the protection of the Nabucco Pipeline from potential discriminatory changes in the law; and support for legislative and administrative actions for the further implementation of the project.{{cite web | title=Nabucco Project Support Agreements finalised and signed | url=http://pipelinesinternational.com/news/nabucco_project_support_agreements_finalised_and_signed/061225/ |publisher=Pipelinesinternational.com | date=9 June 2011 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} In May 2012, the Nabucco consortium submitted a Nabucco-West proposal to the Shah Deniz consortium. On 10 January 2013, Nabucco International and Shah Deniz partners signed a funding agreement. According to the agreement, Shah Deniz partners will take a 50% stake in the project if chosen as an export route for the Shah Deniz gas. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/01/10/energy-gas-nabucco-idUKL5E9CA4RQ20130110 | title = Nabucco pipeline boosts prospects with Azeri deal | agency = [[Reuters]] | first1 = Tsvetelia | last1 = consortium. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/03/04/nabucco-tanap-idUKL6N0BW6LW20130304 | title = Nabucco signs cooperation deal with TANAP | agency = [[Reuters]] | first1 = for its gas exports,{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20130628-703082.html|title=Shah Deniz Project Selects TAP As European Gas Pipeline|date=28 June 2013|accessdate=29 June after rival pipeline wins Azeri gas bid |date=27 June 2013|accessdate=29 June 2013| work =EurActiv}} ==Route== The original {{convert|3893|km}} long pipeline was to run from [[Ahiboz, Gölbaşı|Ahiboz]] in Turkey via Bulgaria, Romania, and Hungary to [[Baumgarten an der March]], a major natural gas hub in Austria. {{cite web |url = http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/pipeline/route |title = Route |publisher = Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH |accessdate = 28 October 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714145834/http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/pipeline/route |archivedate = 14 July 2011 |df = dmy-all }} In Ahiboz, it would be joined with two feeder lines, one connecting to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] in the north ([[South Caucasus Pipeline]]), and the other connecting to [[Iraq]] (pipeline to be built) in the southeast. {{cite press release |url = http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/press/NewsText?p_item_id=8E79E5BF557DCC2DE040A8C0010178CA |title = Nabucco: Modification of feeder line concept |publisher = Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH |date = 23 August 2010 |accessdate = 28 October 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714150717/http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/press/NewsText?p_item_id=8E79E5BF557DCC2DE040A8C0010178CA |archivedate = 14 July 2011 |df = dmy-all }} It would be fed also from the [[Tabriz–Ankara pipeline]]. {{convert|2730|km}} of the pipeline was to be laid in Turkey, {{convert|412|km}} in Bulgaria, {{convert|469|km}} in Romania, {{convert|384|km|mi}} in Hungary, and {{convert|47|km}} in Austria. The modified Nabucco West is to start from the Turkey–Bulgaria border and further to follow the original route. The total length of Nabucco West is {{convert|1329|km}}, with the following distances in each of the below countries: * [[Bulgaria]]: {{convert|424|km}} * [[Romania]]: {{convert|475|km}} * [[Hungary]]: {{convert|383|km}} * [[Austria]]: {{convert|47|km}} From Turkey, the original Nabucco pipeline was proposed to enter Bulgaria and after running {{convert|76|km}} in parallel to the existing gas system connect to the Bulgarian national gas network at the compressor station of village Lozenets in [[Yambol Province]].{{cite web | last = Стайкова | first = Росица | year = 2010 | url = http://grada.bg/37364/%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B1%D1%83%D0%BA%D0%BE-%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%83%D1%87%D0%B8-%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0/ | title = Газопровод "Набуко" получи обществената подкрепа на Върбица | publisher = Шуменска заря | accessdate = 18 January 2011 | language = Bulgarian | ref = harv }} After crossing the [[Balkan Mountains|Balkan Range]], the pipeline will head {{convert|116.3|km}} in a northwesterly direction. After reaching the national northern half-ring, it will run {{convert|133|km}} in parallel to the existing East-West gas line and continue {{convert|86.5|km}} to northwest before reaching the [[Danube]] at [[Oryahovo]]. In Bulgaria, Nabucco will have interconnections with the national gas network and will have two off-take systems, compressor stations and pig stations. {{cite news |url = http://bsanna-news.ukrinform.ua/newsitem.php?id=12642&lang=en |title = Design of Bulgarian Section of Nabucco Pipeline to Be Ready in Late 2011 |publisher = Ukrinform |work = [[Bulgarian News Agency]] |date = 19 March 2010 |accessdate = 20 March 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130419081157/http://bsanna-news.ukrinform.ua/newsitem.php?id=12642&lang=en |archivedate = 19 April 2013 |df = dmy-all }} In Romania, the pipeline will be crossing into the country under the Danube. The route on the Romanian territory will go from south-west to north-west, its south-western starting point being located at the Danube-crossing point upstream the [[Port of Bechet]], and the north-western end point being located north of [[Nădlac]]. The pipe will follow the south western border of Romania and will travel through the counties of [[Dolj County|Dolj]], [[Mehedinţi County|Mehedinti]], [[Caraş-Severin County|Caras-Severin]], [[Timiş County|Timiş]], and [[Arad County|Arad]]. The pipeline will cross 11 protected sites, two national parks, three natural reserves, and 57 watercourses, namely major rivers such as: [[Jiu River|Jiu]], [[Coşuştea River|Coşuştea]], [[Cerna River (Danube)|Cerna]], Bela Reca, [[Timiş River|Timiş]], [[Bega River (Tisza)|Bega]], and [[Mureş River|Mureş]], as well as their tributaries. The terrain is rockier in Romania and mainly constituted of limestone. This section is {{convert|469|km}} long. {{cite web |url = http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/safety/countrie_activities/Environmental%20%20Social%20Impact%20Assessment%20in%20Romania |title = Environmental and Social Impact Assessment in Romania |publisher = [[Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH]] |accessdate = 15 July 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714150218/http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/safety/countrie_activities/Environmental%20%20Social%20Impact%20Assessment%20in%20Romania |archivedate = 14 July 2011 |df = dmy-all }} [[Poland|Polish]] gas company [[Polskie Górnictwo Naftowe i Gazownictwo|PGNiG]] was studying the possibility of building a link from the Nabucco gas pipeline to [[Poland]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=10087 | title = PGNiG Eyes Link To Nabucco | publisher = Downstream Today | agency = [[Agence France-Presse|AFX News Limited]] | date = 14 April 2008 | accessdate = 19 April 2008}} ==Technical features== The Nabucco-West is to be exempt from regulated third party access, including tariff regulation, for 25 years. Its proposal states a capacity of {{convert|10|e9m3|abbr=off}} per year. This capacity will be scaled up to {{convert|23|e9m3|abbr=off}} to compensate for an anticipated increase in demand. Nabucco West will offer 50% of its transport capacity to third parties outside of the shareholders. {{cite web | title=Overview | url=http://www.nabucco-pipeline.com/portal/page/portal/en/pipeline/overview | publisher=Nabucco Pipeline International GmbH | accessdate=12 June 2013}}{{cite web | title=Nabucco West Selected as Potentaial Route for Azeri Gas | url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-06-28/nabucco-west-selected-as-potentaial-route-for-azeri-gas | publisher=Zulfugar Agayev and Zoe Schneeweiss | agency = [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | date=28 June 2012 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} ==Construction== The Nabucco project is included in the EU Trans-European Energy Network programme and a feasibility study for the Nabucco pipeline has been performed under an EU project grant. The [[Front End Loading|front end engineering and design (FEED)]] services of the pipeline, including the overall management of the local FEED contractors, the review of the technical feasibility study, route confirmation, preparation of the design basis, hydraulic studies, overall [[SCADA]] and telecommunications, GIS and preparation of tender packages for the next phase, was managed by UK-based consultancy [[Penspen]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article146737.ece | title = Penspen takes on Nabucco role | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | date = 7 January 2008 | accessdate = 20 April 2008}} Starting from 14 December 2011, [[WorleyParsons]] was appointed as on [[owner's engineer]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.news.az/articles/economy/51414 | title = Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH appointed New Owner's Engineer | agency = News.az | date = 21 December 2011 | accessdate = 26 December 2011}} On 28 January 2013, it was announced that a re-feed for the Nabucco West project is being conducted by [[Saipem]] following the selection of the project as the [[Central Europe]]an route by the [[Shah Deniz gas field|Shah Deniz]] consortium in June last year. This work will build upon existing engineering work already completed for the Nabucco classic route.{{cite web | title=Italian Saipem to perform Front End Engineering and Design services for Nabucco West | url=http://en.trend.az/capital/energy/2113015.html | agency = Trend.az | date=28 January 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} According to [[Reinhard Mitschek]], managing director of [[Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH]], construction of the pipeline was scheduled to begin in 2013 and would become operational by 2017. {{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/06/nabucco-gas-idUSLDE7450JI20110506 | title = Nabucco sees commercial gas transport start in 2017 | agency = [[Reuters]] | first = Peter | last = Harrison | date = 6 May 2011 | accessdate = 6 May 2011}} {{cite news | url = http://www.mediafax.ro/english/nabucco-construction-start-delayed-to-2013-8238514 | title = Nabucco Construction Start Delayed To 2013 | publisher = [[Mediafax]] | date = 6 May 2011 | accessdate = 6 May 2011}} However, in June 2013, the Shah Deniz Consortium had chosen a rival project, [[Trans Adriatic Pipeline]], that has a route Turkey–Greece-Albania-Italy,{{cite news|title=EU-backed Nabucco project 'over' after rival pipeline wins Azeri gas bid|url=http://www.euractiv.com/energy/eu-favoured-nabucco-project-hist-news-528919|publisher=EurActiv.com|date=27 June 2013}} and the future of Nabucco project is unclear. ==Financing== The pipelines costs are undisclosed, however [[Reinhard Mitschek]] said in late 2012 that the costs of Nabucco West would be far lower than €7.9 billion previously suggested.{{cite web | title=Nabucco Gas Pipe’s Cost to Fall on Shorter Route, Mitschek Says | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-11-15/nabucco-gas-pipe-s-cost-to-fall-on-shorter-route-mitschek-says.html | agency=Bloomberg | date=15 November 2012 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} The final investment decision is expected in 2013. The sources of financing of the Nabucco project are not decided yet. As a commercial project, it will be financed 30% by the project's partners and the rest by commercial financial instruments. The European Commission has awarded an EU project grant in the amount of 50% of the estimated total eligible cost of the feasibility study and has also decided to allocate €200 million from the European Economic Recovery Plan. {{cite news | url = http://www.euractiv.com/en/energy/eu-divvies-23bn-electricity-and-gas-infrastructure-news-305783 | title = EU throws €2.3bn at gas, power connections | publisher = EurActiv | date = 4 March 2010 | accessdate = 5 March 2010}} To receive this financing, this grant should be committed by the end 2010. At the Nabucco Summit held in Budapest on 27 January 2009, the heads of the [[European Investment Bank]] (EIB) and the [[European Bank for Reconstruction and Development]] (EBRD) confirmed, that they are prepared to provide financial backing for the project. On 5 February 2010, the EIB vice-president Mathias Kollatz-Ahnensaid that Nabucco consortium is seeking up to €2 billion (20–25% of costs) financing from the bank. The EIB is ready to participate in the financing of this project; however, the precondition is that the partner countries should legally approve the pipeline's transit in their countries. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE61321B20100205?sp=true | first1 = Melis | last1 = Senerdem | first2 = Thomas | last2 = Grove | title = Nabucco seen asking EIB for up to 2 bln euro–EIB | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 5 February 2010 | accessdate = 8 February 2010}} In September 2010, the consortium signed an agreement with EIB, EBRD, and the [[International Finance Corporation]] (IFC), according to which the banks will conduct [[due diligence]] for a financing package of €4 billion. Up to €2 billion will be signed by the EIB, up to €1.2 billion by the EBRD, and up to €800 million by the IFC. {{cite news | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article228613.ece | title = Finance giants run rule over Nabucco | date = 6 September 2010 | accessdate=10 October 2010}} All figures listed above relate to the original Nabucco Project. Updated figures for Nabucco West are undisclosed as of June 2013. Reinhard Mitschek, Managing Director of Nabucco said in an interview with Natural Gas Europe in May 2013 that “Nabucco is continuing to cooperate with the International Financial Institutions to ensure the bankability of the project, a large part of the legal due diligence has already been completed. A Letter of Intent has been signed with the IFIs most recently.”{{cite web | title=Reinhard Mitschek: Nabucco Offers the Biggest Market Access without Hidden Costs | url=http://www.naturalgaseurope.com/reinhard-mitschek-nabucco-west-interview | agency=Natural Gas Europe | date=30 May 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} In a separate interview in February 2013, [[Reinhard Mitschek|Mitschek]] confirmed that all legal and regulatory framework approved for the original Nabucco project would remain valid for Nabucco West.{{cite web | title="Nabucco is a Truly European Project": An Interview with Reinhard Mitschek | url=http://www.naturalgaseurope.com/reinhard-mitschek-nabucco-gas-pipeline-international | agency=Natural Gas Europe | date=14 February 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} ==Supply sources== The potential suppliers for original Nabucco project were considered to be Iraq, Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan, and Egypt. At the first stage, {{convert|10|e9m3|abbr=off}} of natural gas per year were expected from Iraq. {{cite news | url = http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article230940.ece | title = Nabucco sets sights on Iraq | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | date = 30 September 2010 | accessdate = 10 October 2010}} Iraqi gas would be imported via the [[Arab Gas Pipeline]] (extension to be built) from the [[Ekas field]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=10137 | title = EU, Iraq Seek To Seal Nabucco Deal Within Weeks - Barroso | publisher = Downstream Today | agency = [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] | date = 16 April 2008 | accessdate = 19 April 2008}} Turkmenistan would provide {{convert|10|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas per year through [[Iran]] or across the [[Caspian Sea]] via the planned [[Trans-Caspian Gas Pipeline]]. {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE6241WB20100305?sp=true | title = Turkmen gas deal for Nabucco seen in months-RWE exec | first = Melis | last = Senerdem | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 5 March 2010 | accessdate = 5 March 2010}} {{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7347051.stm | title = EU secures Turkmenistan gas deal | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 14 April 2008 | accessdate = 19 April 2008}} {{cite news | url = http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article183268.ece | title = Ashgabat offers gas for Nabucco | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | date = 10 July 2009 | accessdate = 11 July 2009}} {{cite news | url= http://finchannel.com/Main_News/Op-Ed/52227_The_Great_Geopolitical_Battle_Over_Energy_Transit_Routes/ | title= The Great Geopolitical Battle Over Energy Transit Routes | publisher= Finchannel.com | first = Phillip H. | last = de Leon | date=18 November 2009 | volume= | issue= | accessdate=23 November 2009 }} OMV and RWE set up a joint venture, named the Caspian Energy Company, to carry out research for a gas pipeline across the Caspian Sea. {{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/News/Articles/200812/OMV_RWE_Launch_Caspian_Pipeline_JV_14357.aspx | title = OMV, RWE Launch Caspian Pipeline JV | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 22 December 2008 | accessdate = 25 December 2008}} In the long term, [[Kazakhstan]] may become a supplier providing natural gas from the Northern Caspian reserves through the planned Trans-Caspian Gas Pipeline. {{cite journal | first = Shamil | last = Yenikeyeff | url = http://www.oxfordenergy.org/wpcms/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/NG25-KazakhstansgasExportMarketsandExportRoutes-ShamilYenikeyeff-2008.pdf | title= Kazakhstan's Gas: Export Markets and Export Routes | publisher=[[Oxford Institute for Energy Studies]] | format=PDF | date = November 2008 | accessdate=17 November 2011}} Egypt could provide {{convert|3|-|5|e9m3}} of natural gas through the Arab Gas Pipeline. Prime Minister of Turkey [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] has urged Egypt to export natural gas to Europe via the Nabucco pipeline. {{cite news | url = http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000682979&fid=1725 | title = Erdoğan urges Egypt to export gas to Europe via Turkey | newspaper = [[Globes]] | first = Amiram | last = Barkat | date = 15 September 2011 | accessdate = 15 September 2011}} Iran has also proposed to supply gas to Nabucco pipeline and this was backed by Turkey; however, due the political conditions this is rejected by the EU and the United States. {{cite news | url = http://en.rian.ru/world/20080411/104863460.html | title = Iran seen as alternative to Turkmenistan in Nabucco gas project | agency = [[RIA Novosti]] | date = 11 April 2008 | accessdate = 19 April 2008}} {{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL0583264520080605?sp=true | title = US still opposes Iran as Nabucco gas supplier | first = Conor | last = Sweeney | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 5 June 2008 | accessdate = 13 June 2008}} {{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/marketsNews/idUSLC53505820090712?sp=true | title = Russia free to supply gas to Nabucco-U.S. envoy | first = Selcuk | last = Gokoluk | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 11 July 2009 | accessdate = 11 July 2009}} Nabucco-West is designated to carry Azeri gas from the second stage of Shah Deniz through TANAP pipeline. {{cite news |url = http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/128806/turkey-azerbaijan-deal-to-transfer-gas-to-europe.html |title = Turkey, Azerbaijan Deal to Transfer Gas to Europe |first1 = Servet |last1 = Yeşiyurt |first2 = Hüseyin |last2 = Hayatsever |newspaper = [[The Turkish Weekly]] |date = 27 December 2011 |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120105050935/http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/128806/turkey-azerbaijan-deal-to-transfer-gas-to-europe.html |archivedate = 5 January 2012 |df = dmy-all }} The pipeline is able to transport between 10 – 23 BCM annually from the Shah Deniz gas field. [[OMV]], a shareholder in Nabucco, also suggested that Nabucco will be used to transport gas from its Domino-1 deep-sea offshore well in the [[Black Sea]]. The Domino-1 well was OMV’s largest gas find with 1.5 – 3 trillion cubic feet announced in February 2012.{{cite web | title=OMV Says Construction of Nabucco Pipe May Start in 2015 | url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-05-10/omv-says-construction-of-nabucco-pipe-may-start-in-2015 | agency=Bloomberg Businessweek | first=Zoe | last=Schneeweiss | date=10 May 2012 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} ==Project company== The project is developed by the [[Vienna]]-registered Nabucco Gas Pipeline International GmbH. The managing director of the company is Reinhardt Mitschek. {{cite news | url = http://www.cepa.org/digest/interview-with-nabucco-managing-director-reinhardt-mitschek.php | title = Interview with Nabucco Managing Director Reinhardt Mitschek | first = Neil | last = Barnett | publisher = Centre for European Policy Analysis | date = 14 March 2008 | accessdate = 20 April 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080410085121/http://www.cepa.org/digest/interview-with-nabucco-managing-director-reinhardt-mitschek.php |archivedate = 2008-04-10}} The shareholders of the company are: * [[BOTAŞ]] ([[Turkey]]) * [[Bulgarian Energy Holding|BEH]] ([[Bulgaria]]) * [[FGSZ]] (wholly owned subsidiary of [[MOL Group|MOL]]) ([[Hungary]]) * [[OMV]] ([[Austria]]) * [[Transgaz]] ([[Romania]]) Nabucco International is the owner of the five national Nabucco companies responsible for the operation and maintenance of the pipeline in their respective countries. RWE left the project and on 1 March 2013 OMV took over all of RWE's shares. {{cite news | title=OMV buys RWE stake in Nabucco gas pipeline project | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/14/omv-rwe-nabucco-idUSL5N0D10D620130414 | agency=Reuters | first=Michael | last=Shields | date=2 April 2013 | accessdate=14 April 2013}} On 28 May 2013, it was announced that [[GDF Suez]], a French utilities provider, agreed to buy a 9% stake from OMV. {{cite news | title=OMV sells 9 pct Nabucco pipeline stake to GDF SUEZ | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/28/omv-gdf-nabucco-idUSL5N0E90Z220130528 | agency=Reuters | first=Michael | last=Shields | date=28 May 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} ==Alternative projects== [[Image:Nabuccostream.png|thumb|Map of Nabucco and TANAP]] [[Image:Major russian gas pipelines to europe.png|thumb|Major existing and planned natural gas pipelines supplying Russian gas to Europe]] The main competitor for the original project was South Stream. In 2006, [[Gazprom]] proposed an alternative project, in competition with the Nabucco pipeline, that would involve constructing a second section of the [[Blue Stream]] pipeline beneath the [[Black Sea]] to Turkey, and extending this up through Bulgaria and [[Serbia]] to western Hungary. {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/22/business/worldbusiness/22iht-gas.2031021.html | first = Judy | last = Dempsey | title = Gazprom's grip on Western Europe tightens with pipelines to Hungary | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |date = 13 July 2006 | accessdate = 10 November 2007}} In 2007, instead the South Stream project through Bulgaria, Serbia, Hungary and Slovenia to Austria and [[Italy]] was proposed. {{cite news | publisher= [[BBC]] | work= [[BBC News]] | title = Balkan boost for Russian gas plan | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7195522.stm | first = Neil | last = MacDonald | date = 25 February 2008 | accessdate=26 February 2008}} {{cite news |url = http://www.neurope.eu/articles/79576.php |title = Russia prefers South Stream over Blue Stream II |first = Kostis |last = Geropoulos |publisher = New Europe |date = 3 November 2007 |accessdate = 16 May 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080628042521/http://www.neurope.eu/articles/79576.php |archivedate = 28 June 2008 |df = dmy-all }} {{cite news | url = http://downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=16386 | title = Gazprom Agrees To Boost Pipeline Capacity | publisher = Downstream Today | work = [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] | date = 15 May 2009 | accessdate = 16 May 2009}} On 10 March 2010, CEO of [[Eni]], a partner in South Stream, [[Paolo Scaroni]] proposed to merge Nabucco and South Stream projects to "reduce investments, operational costs and increase overall returns". {{cite news | url = http://www.upi.com/Science_News/Resource-Wars/2010/03/11/ENI-calls-for-South-Stream-Nabucco-links/UPI-96591268317232/ | title = ENI calls for South Stream, Nabucco links | publisher = [[United Press International]] | date = 11 March 2010 | accessdate = 20 March 2010}} {{cite news | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=avHMERVnSuec | title = Europe Needs to Push Gas Infrastructure Spending, Scaroni Says | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | first1 = Andres R. | last1 = Martinez | first2 = Jessica | last2 = Resnick-Ault | date = 10 March 2010 | accessdate = 20 March 2010}} This proposal was rejected by energy minister of Russia [[Sergei Shmatko]] saying that "South Stream is more competitive than Nabucco" and that "Nabucco and South Stream are far from being competitors". {{cite news | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ae4.eb4lPqjk | title = Russia Rejects Eni Call to Merge Europe Gas Pipelines | first = Anna | last = Shiryaevskaya | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 15 March 2010 | accessdate = 20 March 2010}} According to [[Nobuo Tanaka]], former executive director of the [[International Energy Agency]], the Nabucco pipeline would be more effective in increasing Europe's energy security than the South Stream project as it would increase the number of gas suppliers. {{cite news | url = http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=113554 | title = Energy Supremo: Nabucco Pipeline Is Best European Solution | publisher = [[Novinite.com (Sofia News Agency)|Novinit]] | date = 24 February 2010 | accessdate = 5 March 2010}} Even more important competitor became TANAP which would follow the Nabucco's original route in Turkey. Therefore, Nabucco consortium modified the project and sees the modified Nabucco-West as a prolongation of TANAP into Central Europe. Nabucco West competed with the Trans Adriatic Pipeline and the [[Interconnector Turkey–Greece–Italy]] projects. Also [[liquefied natural gas]] was seen as competitor to Nabucco and to pipeline projects in general.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Azerbaijan, Georgia, Romania and Hungary are developing [[Azerbaijan–Georgia–Romania Interconnector]] project, which is proposed to transport Azerbaijani gas to Europe in form of LNG. {{cite news | url = http://www.euractiv.com/energy/four-countries-team-lng-nabucco-news-497940 | title = Four countries team up for 'LNG Nabucco' | work = EurActiv | date = 20 September 2010 | accessdate = 15 September 2011}} Increasing availability of LNG from large gas-producing countries in the Middle-East and Africa stresses the economic viability of pipelines. {{cite news | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-24/bp-says-increased-lng-supply-reduces-europe-s-pipe-gas-imports.html | title = BP Says Increased LNG Supply Reduces Europe's Pipe Gas Imports | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | first = Eduard | last = Gismatullin | date = 24 November 2010 | accessdate = 15 September 2011}} ==Controversial aspects== ===Economic and political aspects=== The Nabucco pipeline will supply only a limited number of countries in South-East and Central Europe. In 2013, it was confirmed by Bulgarian President [[Rosen Plevneliev]] that the pipeline would transport gas to a minimum of 16 European countries including the gas hub in [[Baumgarten an der March|Baumgarten]], [[Austria]].{{cite web | title=Mitschek: Nabucco answers Azerbaijan’s strategic consideration | url=http://www.euractiv.com/energy/mitschek-nabucco-answers-azerbai-interview-528108 | work=EurActiv | date=29 May 2013 | accessdate=12 June 2013}} The project has been criticized as uneconomic because there is no guarantee that there will be sufficient gas supplies to make it profitable. The Nabucco Gas Pipeline project, although initially intending to secure gas from Iraq and Iran has readjusted its intentions given the current political and economic instabilities in the two countries. It will initially transport 10 BCM from the Shah Deniz gas field with the ability to increase its capacity to 23 BCM as demand increases, along with supply. One region that could also supply additional gas is the [[Black Sea]], with [[OMV]] and [[Exxon Mobil]] announcing an enormous gas discovery in February 2012.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/22/omv-exxonmobil-romania-idUSWEA291420120222 | title = Petrom/Exxon Black Sea well finds huge gas field-OMV | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 22 February 2012 | accessdate = 15 March 2013}} Iran's Foreign Minister [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] has stated "speaking about the Nabucco pipeline without Iran's participation would amount to nothing but a pipeline void of gas". Russian Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]] has made similar remarks. {{cite news | url= http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=16937 | title= Can The $11.4bn Nabucco Pipeline Work Without Iran? | publisher= Global Research | work = [[Journal of Turkish Weekly]] | first = John C.K. | last = Daly | date=12 January 2010 | accessdate=5 March 2010 }} The deputy chairman of the Russia's [[State Duma]] Energy Committee Ivan Grachev has questioned the viability of the Nabucco project and sees it as an attempt to put pressure on Russia. {{cite news | url= http://www.eu-russiacentre.org/news/russian-mps-criticize-nabucco-gas-pipeline-project.html | title= Russian MPs criticize Nabucco gas pipeline project | publisher= EU–Russia Centre | work = [[Echo of Moscow|Ekho Moskvy]] | date=14 July 2009 | accessdate=16 January 2010 }} This is supported by Russia's gas deals with Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan, which by some observers has been seen as attempt to reserve potential Nabucco supplies. {{cite news | url= http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Bswords%5D=8fd5893941d69d0be3f378576261ae3e&tx_ttnews%5Bany_of_the_words%5D=PKK&tx_ttnews%5Bpointer%5D=3&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=35615&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=7&cHash=48b4642cf5 | title= Azerbaijan-Russia Gas Agreement: Implications for Nabucco Project | publisher= Eurasia Daily Monitor | first = Vladimir | last = Socor | authorlink = Vladimir Socor | date=15 October 2009 | volume=6 | issue=189 | accessdate=23 November 2009 }} {{cite news | url= http://www.jamestown.org/programs/edm/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=35866&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=27&cHash=5d1340eedf | title= Russia Resuming Gas Imports From Turkmenistan on a Small Scale | publisher= Jamestown Foundation | first = Vladimir | last = Socor | authorlink = Vladimir Socor | date=4 January 2010 | volume=7 | issue=1 | accessdate=5 January 2010 }} Azerbaijan has stated that the gas will be transported only through those routes, which would be commercially most attractive. {{cite news | url= http://en.trend.az/capital/pengineering/1619492.html | title= Gas exporters wait for efficient commercial offers: Trend Capital commentator | agency = [[Trend News Agency]] | first = Seymur | last = Aliyev | date=15 January 2010 | accessdate=16 January 2010 }} Also the opening of the [[Central Asia – China gas pipeline]] and the agreements to build the South Stream pipeline has been seen as the end of Nabucco project. {{cite web | url= http://www.ifri.org/?page=detail-contribution&id=5779 | title= Doubts about Nabucco Don't Originate in China - Look to Europe | publisher= [[Institut français des relations internationales]] | first = William C. | last = Ramsay |date=December 2009 | accessdate=25 January 2010 }} However, before the raise of project's costs and the proposal of modified project, RWE had claimed that the transportation of natural gas through the Nabucco pipeline would be cheaper than through South Stream or other alternative pipelines. According to RWE, the transportation of thousand cubic meters of gas from Shah Deniz field to Europe will cost through the Nabucco pipeline €77 versus €106 through the South Stream pipeline. Russian opposition to the pipeline stems from their monopoly over European gas supplies. The Pipeline would lead to cheaper more secure gas supplies for the whole of Europe, due to the decreased influence of the oil linked gas price, this would provide economic benefits to the EU with cheaper energy helping the union become more competitive. NGOs have also criticized the fact that the pipeline results in effective support of the [[authoritarian]] regime in [[Turkmenistan]], which undermines the [[European Union]]'s policy of [[human rights]] promotion.[http://bankwatch.org/our-work/projects/nabucco-gas-pipeline Nabucco gas pipeline], CEE Bankwatch Network. ===Fossil fuels=== Some NGOs criticize the EIB and EBRD for their willingness to finance a fossil fuel project, claiming that it goes against the November 2007 resolution on trade and climate change passed in the European Union Parliament. {{cite news | url= http://bankwatch.org/our-work/projects/nabucco-gas-pipeline | title= Four reason to keep public money away from Nabucco | publisher= [[CEE Bankwatch Network]] | date=4 December 2009 | accessdate=5 June 2013}} The resolution calls for "the discontinuation of public support via export credit agencies and public investment banks, for fossil fuel projects." {{cite journal | url= http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?Type=TA&Reference=P6-TA-2007-0576&language=EN | title= European Parliament resolution of 29 November 2007 on trade and climate change (2007/2003(INI)) | publisher= [[European Parliament]] | date=29 November 2009 | accessdate=23 July 2010 }} Non-governmental organizations also show disapproval, due to the public banks decision to be lenient to Turkmenistan Human and civil rights conditions. {{cite news | url= http://bankwatch.org/documents/OurEnergySecurity.pdf | title= Nabucco and Turkmenistan –our energy security, Turkmen’s misery | publisher= [[CEE Bankwatch Network]] | date=June 2010 | accessdate=23 July 2010 }} ===Security aspects=== Concerns have been raised about the safety of the project. Gas for the Nabucco pipeline coming from Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan will have to pass near areas of instability in the South Caucasus. {{cite news | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article160951.ece | title= BP shuts in Georgia links | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | date = 12 August 2008 | [[File:Nb-SMD-Electrolytic capacitors.png|thumb|SMD chip style of niobium electrolytic capacitors]] A '''niobium electrolytic capacitor''' is a polarized [[capacitor]] whose [[anode]] [[electrode]] (+) is made of passivated [[niobium]] metal or [[niobium monoxide]] on which an insulating [[niobium pentoxide]] layer acts as the [[dielectric]] of the niobium capacitor. A solid [[electrolyte]] on the surface of the oxide layer serves as the second electrode ([[cathode]]) (-) of the capacitor.
Niobium electrolytic capacitors are passive [[electronic component]]s and members of the family of [[electrolytic capacitor]]s.
Niobium capacitors are available as [[Surface-mount technology|SMD]] chip capacitors and compete with [[tantalum capacitor|tantalum]] chip capacitors in certain voltage and capacitance ratings. They are available with a solid [[manganese dioxide]] electrolyte. Niobium capacitors are polarized components by manufacturing principle and may only be operated with [[Direct current|DC]] voltage in correct polarity. Reverse voltage or ripple current higher than specified can destroy the dielectric and thus the capacitor. The destruction of the dielectric may have catastrophic consequences. Manufacturers specify special circuit design rules for the safe operation of niobium capacitors.
Niobium capacitors were developed in the United States as well as in the [[Soviet Union]] in the 1960s. Since 2002 they have been commercially available in the West to take advantage of the lower cost and better availability of niobium compared with tantalum.
==Basic information== Niobium is a sister metal to tantalum. Niobium has a similar melting point (2744 °C) to tantalum and exhibits similar chemical properties. The materials and processes used to produce niobium-dielectric capacitors are essentially the same as for existing tantalum-dielectric capacitors. However, niobium as a raw material is much more abundant in nature than tantalum and is less expensive. The characteristics of niobium electrolytic capacitors and tantalum electrolytic capacitors are roughly comparable.
Niobium electrolytic capacitors can be made with high purity niobium as the anode but the diffusion of oxygen from the dielectric (Nb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>) into the niobium anode metal is very high, resulting in leakage current instability or even capacitor failures. There are two possible ways to reduce oxygen diffusion and improve leakage current stability – either by doping metallic niobium powders with nitride into [[Passivation (chemistry)|passivated]] [[niobium nitride]] or using [[niobium oxide]] (NbO) as anode material. Niobium oxide is a hard ceramic material characterized by high metallic conductivity. Niobium oxide powder can be prepared in a similar structure to that of tantalum powder and can be processed in a similar way to produce capacitors. It also can be oxidized by anodic oxidation ([[anodizing]], forming) to generate the insulating dielectric layer. Thus two types of niobium electrolytic capacitors are marketed, those using a passivated niobium anode and those using a niobium oxide anode. Both types use [[niobium pentoxide]] (Nb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>) as the dielectric layer.
===Basic principle of anodic oxidation=== [[File:Anodic oxidation.jpg|thumb|right|Basic principle of the anodic oxidation, in which, by applying a voltage with a current source, an oxide layer is formed on a metallic anode]]
Niobium is a so-called valve metal such as tantalum and aluminum, on which an electrically insulating oxide layer is formed by anodic oxidation, if a positive voltage is applied. Applying a positive voltage to the [[anode]] material in an [[Electrolyte|electrolytic]] bath forms an oxide [[barrier layer]] with a thickness corresponding to the applied [[voltage]]. This oxide layer acts as [[dielectric]] in an [[electrolytic capacitor]].
For niobium this behavior was known since the beginning of the 20th century. Niobium is more abundant in nature than tantalum and is less expensive but the high melting point of 2744 °C hindered the development of niobium electrolytic capacitors.
In the 1960s, the better availability of niobium ore compared with tantalum ore prompted research into niobium electrolytic capacitors in the former Soviet Union.<ref>Tantalum-Niobium International Study Center, Tantalum and Niobium - Early History [http://tanb.org/history] and Applications for Niobium [http://tanb.org/niobium]</ref> Here they took the place that was filled by tantalum capacitors in the West. With the collapse of the Iron Curtain, this know-how has been publicized in the West. In the late 1990s the interest in this technology awoke in the major capacitor manufacturers. The materials and processes used to produce niobium capacitors are essentially the same as for tantalum capacitors. However, a price rise for tantalum in 2000/2001 encouraged the development of niobium electrolytic capacitors with manganese dioxide electrolyte, as well as polymer electrolyte which have been available since 2002.<ref name=Roadmap /><ref>Ch. Schnitter, A. Michaelis, U. Merker, H.C. Starck, Bayer, New Niobium Based Materials for Solid Electrolyte Capacitors, Carts 2002</ref> [[File:Parallel plate capacitor.svg|thumb|center|A dielectric material is placed between two conducting plates (electrodes), each of area '''''A''''' and with a separation of '''''d'''''.]]
Every electrolytic capacitor in principle forms a "plate capacitor" whose capacitance increases with the electrode area (A) and the [[permittivity]] (ε) and decreases with the thickness (d) of the dielectric.
:<math>C = \varepsilon \cdot \frac{A}{d}</math>
The dielectric thickness of niobium electrolytic capacitors is very thin, in the range of [[Meter|nano-meter]] per volt.<ref name=Moore>J. Moore, Kemet, Nb capacitors compared to Ta capacitors a less costly alternative [http://www.kemet.com/Lists/TechnicalArticles/Attachments/143/V11N01%20Nb%20vs%20Ta%20Capacitors.pdf PDF]</ref> With this very thin dielectric oxide layer, combined with a sufficiently high dielectric strength, the niobium electrolytic capacitors can achieve a high volumetric capacitance comparable to tantalum capacitors. This is one reason for the high capacitance values of electrolytic capacitors compared with other conventional capacitors.
The niobium anode material is manufactured from a powder sintered into a pellet with a rough surface structure intended to increase the electrode surface A compared to a smooth surface of the same area or the same volume. That increases the later capacitance value, depending on the rated voltage, by the factor of up to 200 for solid niobium electrolytic capacitors.<ref>Niobium Powder for Electrolytic Capacitor, JFE TECHNICAL REPORT No. 6 (Oct. 2005) [http://www.jfe-steel.co.jp/en/research/report/006/pdf/006-15.pdf PDF]</ref> The large surface compared to a smooth one is the second reason for the relatively high capacitance values of niobium electrolytic capacitors.
One special advantage is given for all electrolytic capacitors. Because the forming voltage defines the oxide layer thickness the voltage proof of the later electrolytic capacitor can be produced very simple for the desired rated value. That makes electrolytic capacitors fit for uses down to 2 V applications in which other capacitor technologies must stay to much higher limits.
The properties of this niobium pentoxide dielectric layer compared with [[tantalum pentoxide]] layer are given in the following table:<ref name=Karnik>T. Kárník, AVX, NIOBIUM OXIDE FOR CAPACITOR MANUFACTURING , METAL 2008, 13. –15. 5. 2008, [http://www.metal2014.com/files/proceedings/metal_08/Lists/Papers/087.pdf PDF]</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Characteristics of the different tantalum and niobium oxide layers !Anode material ! Dielectric ! Relative permittivity ! Oxide structure ! Breakdown voltage (V/µm) ! Dielectric layer thickness (nm/V) |- |Tantalum|| Tantalum pentoxide Ta<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> || 27 || amorphous || 625 || 1.6 |- |Niobium or Niobium oxide || Niobium pentoxide Nb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>|| 41 || amorphous || 400 || 2.5 |} </center>
The higher permittivity but lower breakdown voltage of niobium pentoxide in niobium capacitors results in capacitors of similar size to those using tantalum pentoxide in tantalum capacitors.
===Basic construction of solid niobium electrolytic capacitors=== <center> <gallery perrow="3" caption=" Construction of a solid niobium chip capacitor" class="centered" mode=packed heights=150px> File:Niobium sintered pellet.png| The capacitor cell of a niobium electrolytic capacitor consist out of sintered niobium or niobium monoxide powder File:Niobium sintered slug.png| Schematic representation of the structure of a sintered niobium electrolytic capacitor with solid electrolyte and the cathode contacting layers File:Niobium-SMD-Chip.png| Construction of a typical SMD niobium electrolytic chip capacitor with solid electrolyte </gallery></center>
A typical niobium capacitor is a chip capacitor and consists of niobium or [[Niobium monoxide|niobium oxide]] powder pressed and [[Sintering|sintered]] into a pellet as the [[anode]] of the capacitor, with the oxide layer of [[tantalum pentoxide]] as [[dielectric]], and a solid [[manganese dioxide]] [[electrolyte]] as the [[cathode]].
===Comparison of niobium and tantalum electrolytic capacitor types=== The combination of anode materials for niobium and tantalum electrolytic capacitors and the electrolytes used has formed a wide variety of capacitor types with different properties. An outline of the main characteristics of the different types is shown in the table below. {| class="wikitable centered" |+ Overview of the key features of niobium and tantalum electrolytic capacitor |- class="hintergrundfarbe6" !Electrolytic capacitor family !Electrolyte !Capacitance range (µF) !Max. rated voltage (V) !Max. temperature (°C) |- |rowspan="3"|Tantalum electrolytic capacitor, sintered anode ||Non-solid, sulfuric acid || 0.1…18,000 || 630|| 125/200 |- | Solid, manganese dioxide || 0.1…3,300|| 125 || 125/150 |- |Solid, polymer || 10…1,500 || 25 || 105 |- |rowspan="2"|Niobium oxide electrolytic capacitor, sintered anode || Solid, manganese dioxide || 1…1,500 || 10 || 105 |- |Solid, polymer || 4.7…470 || 16 || 105 |- |} Tantalum electrolytic capacitors with solid electrolyte as surface-mountable chip capacitors are mainly used in electronic devices in which little space is available or a low profile is required. They operate reliable over a wide temperature range without large parameter deviations.<ref name=Roadmap>T. Zednicek, S. Sita, C. McCracken, W. A. Millman, J. Gill, AVX, Niobium Oxide Technology Roadmap, CARTS 2002 [http://www.avx.com/docs/techinfo/tantniob.pdf PDF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224061725/http://www.avx.com/docs/techinfo/tantniob.pdf |date=2014-02-24 }}</ref><ref name=Moore/><ref name=Karnik/><ref>Y. Pozdeev-Freeman, P. Maden, Vishay, Solid-Electrolyte Niobium Capacitors Exhibit Similar Performance to Tantalum, Feb 1, 2002, [http://powerelectronics.com/content/solid-electrolyte-niobium-capacitors-exhibit-similar-performance-tantalum]</ref><ref>Rutronik, Tantalum & Niobium Capacitors, Technical Standards and Benefits [https://www.rutronik.com/fileadmin/downloads/printmedia/products/02_passive/tantalum_niobium_en.pdf PDF]</ref>
